docs.lead_paragraph: I'm quite amazed that Google is showing the guts to announce that it will no longer censor within China (google.cn) and is prepared to pull out of China altogether. Wow! Finally, a company shows some principles and backbone in this area, after Microsoft Bing censored Chinese-language content worldwide (they claim it was a bug) and Yahoo helped the Chinese government sent dissidents to prison.There are no perfect solutions for dealing with a repressive government, and I made my own share of compromises when I lived for five years in China. I'm a big believer in engagement as a whole, when foreign engagement amounts to a watchdog and boosts civil society. But instead so many foreign companies have acted as lapdogs and facilitated censorship and surveillance, while refusing to speak up for the values they claim to be committed to.

headline.main: Google Refuses to Kowtow

docs.lead_paragraph: As a child Ray Solomonoff developed what would become a lifelong passion for mathematical theorems, and as a teenager he became captivated with the idea of creating machines that could learn and ultimately think. In 1952 he met Marvin Minsky, a cognitive scientist who was also exploring the idea of machine learning, and John McCarthy, a young mathematician. And within four years, they and seven other scientists, as part of the original Dartmouth Summer Research Project, had founded a new field and given it a name: artificial intelligence.

headline.main: Ray Solomonoff, 83; Made Machines Think

docs.lead_paragraph: Let's see Microsoft try to use these blurbs in their next Xbox campaign: the Sony PlayStation video game console has been criticized by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, not because he finds Assassin's Creed II oddly unengaging or is growing impatient for the release of Final Fantasy XIII, but because he believes that it is "poison" and will lead children down a capitalist "road to hell," Agence France-Presse reported. On his weekly radio and television show, Mr. Chávez said, "Those games they call 'PlayStation' are poison. Some games teach you to kill." He added that violent video games are sold by capitalist countries so they can "later sell weapons," and they "promote the need for cigarettes, drugs and alcohol so they can sell them," according to Agence France-Presse. In October, Venezuela passed a law making it illegal to sell violent video games, an offense punishable by up to five years in prison. Mr. Chávez has previously criticized Nintendo for promoting "selfishness, individualism and violence," and that was before the company released New Super Mario Bros. Wii, which is, like, totally impossible.

headline.main: Postmodern Warfare: Chávez Says PlayStation Will 'Teach You to Kill'

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has handed a new weapon to lobbyists. If you vote wrong, a lobbyist can now tell any elected official that my company, labor union or interest group will spend unlimited sums explicitly advertising against your re-election. ''We have got a million we can spend advertising for you or against you -- whichever one you want,' '' a lobbyist can tell lawmakers, said Lawrence M. Noble, a lawyer at Skadden Arps in Washington and former general counsel of the Federal Election Commission.

headline.main: Lobbies' New Power: Cross Us, And Our Cash Will Bury You

docs.abstract: Supreme Court decision lifting restrictions on corporate spending in political campaigns is expected to unleash torrent of attack advertisements from outside groups aiming to sway voters, without candidate having to take criticism for dirty campaigning; biggest beneficiaries may be well-placed incumbents who companies and interest groups are eager to court; it could also have big impact on state and local governments, where several million dollars can have enormous influence on elections; ruling comes as influence-seekers of all kinds have special incentives to contribute; Democrats predict that Republicans will benefit most from decision, because they are traditional allies of big corporations, which have more to spend than unions; Republicans dispute partisan impact of ruling, arguing that Democrats have proven effective at cultivating their own business allies; Democrats vow to push legislation to install new spending limits in time for midterm elections; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: How do you get to Sundance? Perseverance, perspiration and, if possible, private jets: on Sunday Bill Pullman and Jessica Alba blew in from the left coast on a tiny aircraft to attend the premiere of Michael Winterbottom's "The Killer Inside Me," which was certainly one way of skirting the weather problems that kept many so many grounded in cities like Los Angeles and Phoenix. As a result, people have for days been trickling in to American cinema's annual indie bacchanal, and when they finally got here, they found more snow in Park City, Utah, than during any Sundance in years - a constant, muted downfall that didn't let up until Sunday but that certainly didn't stop the hordes of stockingless young women clad in miniskirts and stilettos from swarming into the mush-and-ice covered downtown. Mardi Gras beads were strewn all over Main Street on Sunday morning, which was probably a metaphor for something. But the fact that so much of the festival has nothing to do with movies is a pretty straightforward statement about what Sundance has become - namely, a brand to be readily exploited by whoever wants to set up shop and give away medicated lip gloss. Still, there are pearls among the swine.

headline.main: Sundance 2010 | The Big Bing

docs.lead_paragraph: After months of feverish speculation, Steven P. Jobs introduced Wednesday what Apple hopes will be the coolest device on the planet: a slender tablet computer called the iPad. For all the hoopla surrounding it, however, the question is whether the iPad can achieve anything close to the success of the iPhone, which transformed the cellphone and forced the industry to race to catch up.

headline.main: With Its Tablet, Apple Blurs Line Between Devices

docs.abstract: Steven Jobs introduces slender tablet computer called iPad, which Apple hopes will be its new coolest device; it is being positioned as pioneer in new genre of computing, somewhere between laptop and smartphone; iPad is half-inch thick and weighs 1-1/2 pounds and will vividly display books, newspapers, Web sites and videos on 9.7-inch touch screen; it is hailed as new era for publishing, as it gives media another way to sell content; device, which will be priced between $499 and $829, lacks some features common on laptops and phones; critics say it is little more than oversized iPod touch, pointing out that it lacks phone and cannot run Flash, software that handles video and animation on Web; also missing is alternative to AT&T data network, which is already buckling under strain of iPhone traffic; question surrounding rollout is whether iPad can achieve success of iPhone, which transformed cellphone and forced industry to play catch-up; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Apple is positioning its new tablet computer as something between a laptop and a smartphone.

docs.lead_paragraph: Every year, Microsoft holds a show-and-tell extravaganza in which its researchers from around the globe gather in Redmond, Wash., to demonstrate their fanciest technology. Last week, Microsoft provided reporters with a glimpse of some of this wizardry and gave a hands-on session with its Project Natal gaming system. Natal is the gesture control add-on that Microsoft plans to sell for its Xbox 360 consoles later this year. It lets people ditch their traditional game controllers. A flick of your wrist translates on-screen to a flick of the wrist, and the same goes for a kick, head bob or bend.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chemistry students and teachers might want to check out the new Chem4Word add-on for Microsoft Word. The free software, which was developed by Microsoft Research and the Unilever Center for Molecular Science Informatics at the University of Cambridge, allows Word users to insert chemical symbols, formulas and even 2-D models of molecules into documents. Chem4Word works with Word 2007 and the current beta version of Word 2010, and is listed as a beta version itself. More information and a demonstration video are also available for scientists, aspiring scientists and those who have chemistry papers due soon.

docs.lead_paragraph: Q.Is there a way to schedule sending a message in Outlook instead of right when I write it?A.Outlook 2007 includes a feature to easily delay the delivery of a single message or all of them. If your Internet service provider uses a POP3 mail system, however, you do need to keep the Outlook program open until the messages are actually sent off. When you have finished writing the message you want to delay, select the Options tab. In the More Options area in the Outlook toolbar ribbon, click on the Delay Delivery icon. When the Message Options box appears, go to the Delivery Options area and put a check in the box next to ''Do not deliver before.'' Select the time and date you want the message to leave. Once you have your delivery time set, click the Close button.

docs.lead_paragraph: Before he goes to sleep, between 11 and midnight, Dan Pfeiffer, the White House communications director, typically checks in by e-mail with the same reporter: Mike Allen of Politico, who is also the first reporter Pfeiffer corresponds with after he wakes up at 4:20. A hyperactive former Eagle Scout, Allen will have been up for hours, if he ever went to bed. Whether or not he did is one of the many little mysteries that surround him. The abiding certainty about Allen is that sometime between 5:30 and 8:30 a.m., seven days a week, he hits ''send'' on a mass e-mail newsletter that some of America's most influential people will read before they say a word to their spouses. Allen's e-mail tipsheet, Playbook, has become the principal early-morning document for an elite set of political and news-media thrivers and strivers. Playbook is an insider's hodgepodge of predawn news, talking-point previews, scooplets, birthday greetings to people you've never heard of, random sightings (''spotted'') around town and inside jokes. It is, in essence, Allen's morning distillation of the Nation's Business in the form of a summer-camp newsletter.

headline.main: The Insiders' Insider

docs.abstract: Politico reporter Mike Allen's e-mail tipsheet Playbook has become principal early-morning document for elite set of political and news-media thrivers and strivers; Politico, which is often at odds with White House, stands in stark contrast to chatty hodgepodge format and content of Playbook; Allen, who is obsessively private and reported to be hoarder, produces different content than most Politico columnists, but still embodies 24-hour dedication and break-neck pace of other journalists; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Sundance) THE MATADOR (2008) As a boy in Granada, Spain, David Fandila, above, would fight imaginary bulls with his mother's dish towels. He grew up to confront real bulls, some weighing 1,300 pounds or more, to his mother's dismay. This documentary from Stephen Higgins and Nina Gilden Seavey chronicles Mr. Fandila's quest to reach 100 fights in a single season, a goal only 12 matadors have achieved. ''Barbaric, elegant, primitive, erotic, revolting, thrilling: the movie, like bullfighting itself, is all of these,'' Jeannette Catsoulis wrote in The New York Times. ''Blessed with a charismatic leading man, an arcane setting (bullfighting has roots in Roman sacrificial religion), and a narrative steeped in blood and hand-to-hoof combat -- not to mention a triumphant six-bull climax -- the film is a Hemingway fantasy.'' 9:30 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Liz Claman starts the countdown to her 500th show, to be broadcast on Wednesday, by interviewing Warren E. Buffett, the chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway; Charlie Munger, its vice chairman; and Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, on the heels of the annual Berkshire Hathaway shareholder meeting in Omaha. The topics include the economy, new investing opportunities, Goldman Sachs and Wall Street reform.

docs.lead_paragraph: Overview | Is PowerPoint a valuable tool, or does it stifle critical thinking and innovative presentation of material? How can information be presented visually using PowerPoint without falling into the trap of simplistic bullet-point prose? In this lesson, students examine perspectives on effective and ineffective uses of PowerPoint, then develop a set of rules for effective use of this tool for their class projects and presentations. They then create PowerPoint slides and a prose narrative on the same subject and compare the impact of each on the intended audience.

docs.lead_paragraph: MURPHY--Charles E. "Ted", 52, manager of digital archival resources, died April 5 at his home in Cambridge, MA after a brief illness. He was born in Providence, RI. A trustee Scholar at Boston University, he earned joint baccalaureates, magna cum laude, in English and History in 1976. He started archival training as a BU undergrad. After graduation he became exhibit coordinator and junior archivist and assisted Taylor Branch in research for Pulitzer Prize winning Studies of Civil Rights Movement, becoming deeply versed in BU's collection of Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers. In 1984, he earned MBA from BU in marketing and finance and moved to Manhattan, his home for over two decades. He worked for American Theatre Wing; The Foundation Center; Scribner Encyclopedia of American Lives: The 1960's writing essays on Lady Bird Johnson, philanthropist Stewart Mott and former Yale president Kingman Brewster Jr. From 1995-2002 he was editor and writer at online journal Baseline where he wrote over 600 film reviews and interviewed more than 100 celebrities. He collaborated with Microsoft writing and editing over 400 entries for CD-Rom "Cinemania". He established his own film review website and became a founder of New York Film Critics Online. In 2007 he returned to BU as manager of Gotlieb Center's Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Archival Collaborative creating an online finding aid for the King papers in Boston and Atlanta using a new computer application he helped develop. Survivors include his sister, Mary G. Murphy of New Hampshire and cousins in Rhode Island. A.J. Spears Funeral Home of Cambridge handled services. There is a 4pm memorial service on May 22 at The Algonquin Club in Boston. RSVP 617-353-1225 or cfgately@bu.edu.

docs.lead_paragraph: When business owners visit our firm to discuss the sale of their businesses, they are often accompanied by another person. Typically that person is a spouse, lawyer, accountant, partner with an equity stake or family member who works in the business. But every so often the other person is introduced as ''a friend.'' At this point I hope for the best but prepare mentally for the worst. I sometimes refer to these people as an F.O.B. (friend of the business). More often than not, the F.O.B. and the owner were friends in another life -- high school, college, church or a stint with a previous employer. It usually takes a few probing questions to decipher the role of the F.O.B. in the organization.

headline.main: The Pitfalls Of Hiring Friends

docs.abstract: You're the Boss blog explores hiring friends for important jobs in small businesses; holds it can work, but can also be disaster (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As Swiss lawmakers lock horns over a bill to resolve a thorny tax dispute between UBS and Washington, one thing is becoming clear: an end to absolute banking secrecy will change the country's pre-eminent financial sector. Niche private banks previously specializing in undeclared assets in Geneva and Zurich will have to adapt, and some may go under, analysts and academics predict. Those that remain will find themselves with fewer assets to manage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gala Darling is not the kind of girl who would normally sell you a smartphone. She imagines herself as a "a psychedelic picture show," with platinum (formerly blue, then hot pink) hair, trippy Alexander McQueen bondage heels and Chloé 2148 sunglasses. A Kiwi by birth, a New Yorker by inclination, the 26-year-old is a devotee of the byzantine echo chamber known as "social media," with 10,320 followers on Twitter and 4,357 friends on Facebook. She signs her blog posts - on fashion and also on "how to live magically" - with "love letters and feather headdresses." Her next book, on "radical self-love," is only "partially about masturbation." People read her - lots of people, judging by the hundreds of comments her posts routinely generate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Judge Weighs Gang Injunction | The latest effort by regional law enforcement authorities to use the court system to control gang violence will be under the microscope in Alameda County Superior Court, where officials will press for an injunction to control Oakland's North Side gang. It would restrain 15 named individuals from a variety of activities, including weapons possession, trespassing and witness intimidation. It would also keep suspected gang members from associating with one another in a 100-block swath of the city and impose a curfew from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. In other Bay Area cities, like Fairfield, civil liberties groups have attacked such injunctions as violations of constitutional rights. In Oakland, opponents argue that an injunction would do little to curb crime and much to prompt racial profiling. A report in The Bay Citizen said that a series of at least four killings put law enforcement's focus on the north Oakland group. [The Oakland Tribune, The New York Times, The Bay Citizen]Proposition Billed as Antidote to Polarization | Proposition 14, backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, is gaining traction. The initiative would replace traditional primaries in state and Congressional elections with twofold elections. All candidates would run in the first round. The top two vote-getters, regardless of party affiliation, or lack thereof, would face each other in the general election. Voters' ultimate choice could be two Republicans or two Democrats, but it is likely that they would be the best-known or the wealthiest of the original field. Supporters say the measure would empower moderates and increase turnout. The state's $19 billion deficit, high unemployment and low morale may help the measure's chances; polls show a majority of voters favor it. [The New York Times]

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, Alison Leigh Cowan and David Walter wrote an article about dorm rooms at local colleges that once were occupied by famous people. At Princeton, four young women living in Adlai E. Stevenson's suite said they had never heard of the two-time presidential candidate, but thought maybe they, too, could become famous someday. Yale has Anderson Cooper's old room at D11, Durfee Hall, and Paul Giamatti's room at C52, Vanderbilt Hall. Scores of people responded on the City Room blog, sharing their own dorm-room pedigrees. Some of their memories might be more reliable than others. Excerpts follow:

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft will release its new version of its office suite, Office 2010, on Tuesday. Microsoft Office, which encompasses the workplace staples Word, Excel and Outlook, has dominated sales this year, along with iWork, the Apple productivity application that is compatible with Word and Excel documents. Office 2010 tweaks its core products and introduces Web Apps, online versions of Word, Excel (above), OneNote and PowerPoint. These will compete with an application that is not on the top sellers list because it is free: Google Docs, the so-called cloud computing productivity programs that users can reach from any computer. Office 2010 users will be able to store documents online, giving them universal access, too. SHELLY FREIERMAN

That could be crippling for AdMob, which is the No. 1 seller of ads in iPhone apps. Omar Hamoui, the chief executive of AdMob, said the policy could hurt developers too.

docs.lead_paragraph: Knock, Knock. Who's there? Apple TV? Apple TV who? In September 2006, Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, announced news of the company's latest offering: the Apple TV. Mr. Jobs had high hopes for his latest creation, so high that he told his audience that he hoped the Apple TV would be a fourth leg to the Apple business among PCs and iPods and iPhones. When the Apple TV was unveiled a few months later in early 2007, Mr. Jobs reiterated these comments in an interview with USA Today:We've got two strong legs on our chair today - we have the Mac business, which is a $10 billion business, and music, our iPod and iTunes business, which is $10 billion. We hope the iPhone is the third leg on our chair, and maybe one day Apple TV will be the fourth leg.Yet it wasn't long before Apple downgraded its hopes of a living room accessory and fourth leg to its business, and Mr. Jobs started referring to the poor Apple TV as a ''hobby.''

headline.main: Apple Aims to Re-enter Living Room

docs.lead_paragraph: Simple backup has always been an oxymoron. But I just tried a device that could change that: The Clickfree C2N drive can automatically back up Windows PCs and Macs over a home network with real set-it-and-forget-it ease. The 500-gigabyte Clickfree C2N costs $180 (it's $142 at Amazon), and that's definitely a premium over standard 2.5-inch 500-gigabyte external drives, which sell for $120 or less. But the C2N can be a truly digital-life-saving device for those who can't commit to regular backups.

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft Office 2010 came out this summer, and users who made the leap from Office 2003 or earlier may find the "ribbon" that replaces the on-screen toolbars to be confusing. To help newcomers get used to the ribbon, Microsoft has made a game of it. Ribbon Hero, released this year, is a tool that combines casual gaming with interactive software training to teach users how to find commands in the ribbon for Word, Excel, PowerPoint and OneNote. While the experimental game may not be for everyone (or for those who wish the ribbon were more intuitive in the first place), it may help ease some frustration for others. Ribbon Hero is free to download.

docs.lead_paragraph: I know I raised some eyebrows a few months ago when I wrote that the economy was turning around ("Here Comes the Recovery!"). While lots of folks commented that they, too, were experiencing a resurgence in their business over the past few quarters, there seemed to be just as many naysayers who saw only dark clouds ahead. With the recent news that gross domestic product grew at a less-than-expected 2.4 percent in the second quarter (down from a revised 3.7 percent in the first quarter), the naysayers (including economists) who are predicting a double-dip recession are getting louder than ever.

headline.main: Still Upbeat About the Recovery

docs.lead_paragraph: Berkeley, Calif. THE news of the day often includes an item about some development in artificial intelligence: a machine that smiles, a program that can predict human tastes in mates or music, a robot that teaches foreign languages to children. This constant stream of stories suggests that machines are becoming smart and autonomous, a new form of life, and that we should think of them as fellow creatures instead of as tools. But such conclusions aren't just changing how we think about computers -- they are reshaping the basic assumptions of our lives in misguided and ultimately damaging ways.

headline.main: The First Church of Robotics

docs.abstract: Jaron Lanier Op-Ed article contends that advancement of artificial intelligence is prompting some people to draw misguided and damaging conclusions about how computers are shaping modern society; argues that artificial intelligence does not give people license to avoid accountability by pretending that machines can take on more and more human responsibility; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Yields on 10-year Treasury securities, a vital benchmark for home mortgages and corporate loans, tumbled to the lowest level in more than a year on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve said it would buy up government debt in an effort to bolster the nation's increasingly fragile economy. With no more room to reduce interest rates by decree, the Fed has decided to use its considerable market influence instead. By committing to buy up United States debt, the Fed hopes to increase demand for Treasury securities, pushing up their price while reducing their yields and, in turn, a range of interest rates.

headline.main: 10-Year Treasury Yields Slide On Fed's Decision to Buy Debt

docs.abstract: Ten-year Treasury yields, vital benchmark for home mortgages and corporate loans, drop to 2.765 percent, lowest level in more than year, after Federal Reserve decision to purchase government debt in effort to boost struggling economy; yields on mortgage securities issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac fall to record lows; Fed hopes move will increase demand for securities, pushing up price while reducing yields and range of interest rates; Dow Jones industrial average falls 54.50 points, or 0.51 percent, to 10,664.25; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 6.73 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,121.06; Nasdaq composite index loses 28.52 points, or 1.24 percent, to 2,277.17; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: From Reuters Breakingviews:

headline.main: Variable Pricing and Net Neutrality

docs.abstract: It is easy to frame the debate over net neutrality as an ideological battle between forces who want unfettered Internet access and those who would prevent it. But as with most bitter fights, it is largely a dispute over money.

docs.lead_paragraph: The shoes that Julie Matlin recently saw on Zappos.com were kind of cute, or so she thought. But Ms. Matlin wasn't ready to buy and left the site. Then the shoes started to follow her everywhere she went online. An ad for those very shoes showed up on the blog TechCrunch. It popped up again on several other blogs and on Twitpic. It was as if Zappos had unleashed a persistent salesman who wouldn't take no for an answer.

headline.main: Seeing That Ad on Every Site? You're Right. It's Tracking You.

docs.abstract: People have grown accustomed to being tracked online and shown ads for categories of products they have shown interest in, but increasingly, ads are for specific products that they have perused; while technique, which ad industry calls personalized retargeting or remarketing, is not new, it is becoming more pervasive as companies like Google and Microsoft have entered field; retargeting has reached level of precision that is leaving consumers with palpable feeling that they are being watched as they roam virtual aisles of online stores; in digital advertising business, this form of highly personalized marketing is being hailed as latest breakthrough because it tries to show consumers right ad at right time; some people, though, find it disturbing; with more consumers queasy about intrusions into their privacy, technique is raising anew threat of industry regulation; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TORONTO-Mild-mannered, soft-spoken, and beaming broadly, the Microsoft chairman Bill Gates looked every bit the benevolent businessman as he took the stage at the Toronto International Film Festival on Saturday evening, to help plug the education-reform documentary "Waiting for 'Superman.'" Mr. Gates appears in the film, and, with his wife Melinda, heads a foundation that has invested heavily in improvements to education. But his aw-shucks manner couldn't hide the fact that some of the proposals he tossed off on stage at the Winter Garden theater here were volatile stuff. "We're investing in building these evaluation systems," Mr. Gates said. He was referring to systems that would evaluate the performance of public school teachers, with an eye toward ending the current tenure system under which many teachers now work, and providing a way to weed out the worst teachers, while, perhaps, rewarding the best. He also mentioned, at least twice, changes to teacher pension systems.

headline.main: Bill Gates Stirs Up the Education Debate in Toronto

docs.abstract: Mr. Gates argued that national standards for evaluating teacher and student performance would be a plus.
docs.snippet: Mr. Gates argued that national standards for evaluating teacher and student performance would be a plus.

docs.lead_paragraph: Should New York City charter schools be required to have parent associations like regular public schools? From that basic question comes the first charter school controversy of the new school year. Those who back mandatory parent associations for charters see the issue as a matter of principle and of parents' rights. Those who oppose them do so either on technical grounds - that the New York City schools chancellor does not have authority over charter schools that he did not authorize (about 40 percent of the city's charters were authorized by the State University of New York) or on theoretical grounds: that the whole point of charter schools is that they should be free of such mandates.

The company is legally shielded from liability for what users post. But prosecutors pressed Craigslist to close the section, saying it facilitated prostitution and other sex crimes. docs.lead_paragraph: So, there's kind of clunky but blissfully free PC video chat on Skype and any number of other Web services. And now there's superhigh-quality chat over your TV from Cisco for $898.88, for a year of service. On Wednesday, Cisco unveiled its long-awaited Umi (you-me) videoconferencing system aimed at consumers. The Umi rig includes a camera that fits on the top of a high-definition TV and a rectangular appliance that connects to the TV and Internet, while also handling the processing of the video data. The hardware costs $599, while Cisco's calling service will cost $24.99 a month.

docs.lead_paragraph: Mozilla, the maker of the open-source Firefox Web browser, said Thursday that it would appoint Gary Kovacs, a veteran software executive, as its new chief executive. The appointment ends a nearly six-month search that began after John Lilly, who has been Mozilla's chief executive for the last three years, announced that he would leave to join Greylock Partners, a venture capital firm. Mr. Kovacs is currently senior vice president in charge of mobile products at SAP, the German software giant. Before that, he was a senior executive at SAP-owned Sybase. Between 2003 and 2008, he held various senior executive positions at Macromedia, and later, at Adobe, after those two companies merged.

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether you realize it or not, you may be relating to your computer as if it were human. Professor  Nass's new book, with Corina Yen, is called "The Man Who Lied to His Laptop: What Machines Teach Us About Human Relationships."

docs.lead_paragraph: The keyboard shortcut for Undo - also known as Control-Z in Windows or Command-Z on a Mac - has saved many Microsoft Word files from accidental deletions or unintended formatting over the years. But what if you move too quickly and actually meant to keep the text or formatting the way it was? In Word, the cure for a premature Undo command is Control-Y or Command-Y, which repeats your last action before you "undid" it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Video games and the people who play them are now so diverse that buying games for others, and perhaps even for yourself, has actually become a bit more confusing. For me, the key to a great game is the interplay between the freedom to do what I want in an interesting game world and the sets of rules, constraints and specific goals that give the experience direction and purpose. Of course, a great game for children will rarely do that in the same way as an engrossing experience for adults. So to be clear, these are some of my favorite games of 2010. I'm an adult, so most of these games are for adults. They generally contain violence and are at times profane. They are also a ton of fun and each is engrossing in its own way. If you're looking for excellent games for children and the whole family, please see my gift guide for the Arts section of The New York Times. Grown-ups, step forth.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Megalobster There may be nothing new under the sun, but there's a lot of weird stuff in the water. Way more than we thought, according to the Census of Marine Life, a project 10 years in the making that involved 2,700 scientists in 80 countries who put together ''a map of where we haven't been,'' according to Ron O'Dor, one of the program's senior scientists. Using everything from fancy submersibles to old seafood-restaurant menus, the scientists produced more than 2,600 papers, the highlights of which were released in a 64-page report in October. Among the ''large, active and conspicuous organisms'' that no one knew existed is a new species of spiny lobster, Palinurus barbarae, which was found by a Spanish fishing boat on the Walters Shoals in the Indian Ocean, 400 nautical miles south of Madagascar, and classified by South African marine biologists. It's more than half a meter long. ''This was a lobster that had never been described,'' O'Dor says.

docs.lead_paragraph: NEAR THE HEIGHT OF the 1980s merger boom, C. K. Prahalad and Gary Hamel sat down at Prahalad's home in Ann Arbor, Mich., to hash out a new theory of business success. The two men, both business-school professors, had already written about an idea they called strategic intent, which held that a company's aspirations mattered at least as much as its resources. The history of business, they pointed out, was in large part a history of Davids knocking off Goliaths, as Microsoft did to I.B.M., Wal-Mart did to Sears and Toyota did to Detroit. Their new theory added a twist. Not only was size overrated, but the combination of two companies that sold similar products -- then in vogue -- was overrated, too. Apple and Dell might both be computer companies, but they would make terrible partners because their expertise -- design in one case, logistics in the other -- differed so much. Companies instead tended to thrive when they focused on what they knew best, Hamel and Prahalad wrote. They called their idea ''core competence.''

docs.lead_paragraph: A red-hot trading market has developed in the shares of the world's leading social-networking companies: Facebook, Twitter, Zynga and LinkedIn. What is unusual is that none of the companies are listed on a public stock exchange. Each is privately held. Now, the Securities and Exchange Commission wants to learn more about the business of these stock trades. The agency has sent information requests to several participants in the buying and selling of these four companies' stocks, according to two people with direct knowledge of the inquiry who requested anonymity because they were not authorized to speak about it.

headline.main: Scrutiny For Shares Of Start-Ups

docs.lead_paragraph: Facebook likes big numbers - it now has more than 500 million users, each one of whom can have as many as 5,000 friends. Yet as a privately held company, its ownership base must remain small, or it will have to disclose publicly its financial results. A surging shadow market in the privately held shares of Facebook is making such restraint difficult and could spur the company to go public - even as its executives try to tamp down speculation about an initial public offering - much as similar pressure helped push Microsoft and Google toward their own initial public offerings.

headline.main: Share Rules Could Push An Offering By Facebook

docs.abstract: Prospects for initial public offering by Facebook grow stronger as surging shadow market in privately held shares and growing user base is increasingly making it difficult for company to remain private; similar pressure helped push Microsoft and Google toward their own initial public offerings; Securities and Exchange Commission is reported to have asked for information on Facebook, as well as Twitter, Zynga and LinkedIn; exact focus of inquiry is unclear, but legal experts say agency is likely looking into established shareholder limits for private companies, which could force Facebook's hand; photo (M)
